labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Move signature to Payload
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
Move signature to Payload

Having the signature in the option is bad for two reasons: I makes fragmentation far worse, and it means that the recipient need to look up the signature length, just to parse the OSCORE option. For these reasons the signature belongs in the payload.

I just made a Pull request for this. The pull request also update the compression section to align with draft-ietf-core-object-security-15. Someone should probably go through the draft and align it with draft-ietf-core-object-security-15

issues.title: Deterministic ECDSA
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
If ECDSA is used, Group OSCORE should probably recommend the deterministic ECDSA as is done in EDHOC and TLS 1.3:

"If ECDSA is supported, "deterministic ECDSA" as specified in RFC6979 is RECOMMENDED."

issues.title: kid parameter
issues.author: petervanderstok
issues.body:
in section 3.2 it is unclear what the 'unprotected' field of the message is.
Probably the oscore option is meant. If yes, mark as such. This is confusing.

in section 3.1 the aad array is composed of request_kid and request_piv. It is idifficult to guess why the request_ prefix is added to kid and piv. Why not request_ oscore_version request_algorithms and request_options to be consistent? Or remove request_ everywhere.

Th same issue is marked for oscore

issues.title: Choice of signature Algorithm(s)
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
I think we need some more discussion of which signature algorithms to use. Candidates would be:

Algorithm                 Signature size    Security level
ECDSA secp224r1 (P-224)   56 bytes          112
ECDSA secp256r1 (P-256)   64 bytes          128
ECDSA secp256k1           64 bytes          128
Ed25519                   64 bytes          128

The CFRG review of EDHOC brought up the qeustion if not P-224 would be a better choice if the main goal is to get smaller messages. ECDSA with P-224 has the obvious advantage of having signatures that are 8 bytes shorter.

112-bit security is according to NIST ok to use until 2030.

ECDSA wih P-224 is significantly faster than ECDSA with P-256, around 2/3 the number of operations/time. secp256k1 is around 300 % faster than secp256r1. Harder to find comparisions with Ed25519. Most of the speed will depend on the curve, but EdDSA (Schnorr) also have other advantages that speed up signing compared to ECDSA. Ed25519 verify is likely at least as fast as ECDSA with P-224 on all platforms and significantly faster for signing on all platforms. On some platforms I think Ed25519 is significantly faster also for verification.

In terms of number of implementation, I think ECDSA with P-256 in is the lead, with ECDSA P-224 as second, and Ed25519 in last place.

I am leaning towards that P-224 should probably be supported (then ES224 need to be standardized in COSE). The other three are already registered for COSE. The harder question is which should be MTI. Several people have stated that latency is of uthermost importance, in case the current choice of Ed25519 as MTI is likely the correct choice.

A good but a little bit dated comparision of different algorithms on ARM processors:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/92/materials/slides-92-lwig-3

The choice also depends on if there are fast implementations available. Assembly optimized version of the NIST curves is likely as fast or faster than a curve25519 implementation written in C.

https://github.com/kmackay/micro-ecc has very fast implementations (for ARM) of ECDH and ECDSA with secp160r1, secp192r1, secp224r1, secp256r1, and secp256k1. I cannot find anything similar for EdDSA.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
The text added with the commit above is aligned to the rationale used in EDHOC [1], thus expecting not-too-constrained devices to support both EdDSA and ECDSA, while constrained devices to support EdDSA or ECDSA. The same rationale applies also to the support of curves X25519 and P-256 for Diffie-Hellman secret calculation.

[1] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-lake-edhoc-11#section-7

issues.title: Gateway applications with Group OSCORE
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
This use cases seem to have been forgotten. It is not mentioned in the Group OSCORE document, and I do not think there was any discussion ending in that the use case should not be supported.

Use case description from Jim Schaad:

> 
> I have a room full of light bulbs and switches which constitute a multicast group.  For various reasons these devices do not both doing any signature checking.  There are some additional controllers that live outside of the subnet which consists of the room which need to be able to control the devices and query the state of various devices in the that subsystem.  
>     
> There lives a firewall/gateway on the border between the subsystem and the entire network that wants to prevent unauthenticated commands coming in from the outside or information which is not authenticated leaking out from the inside.  The first way to do this is to make the firewall/gateway be a traffic re-writing system.  That means that it will receive commands from the outside, authenticate them, translate them to a command the will work inside of the room and sends it.  It will then deal with the responses and translate them back to a format that the original device would understand and authenticate.
>     
> The second way is to say that the firewall/gateway is not a trusted party to this situation.  However, there is a desire to drastically cut down the attack space that is coming from the outside world into the room.  In this case when the gateway receives a request, it validates the signature on the group message and ensures that it is signed by a member of the group.  It does this by checking the counter signature on the message, but does not try and decrypt the message.  At that point it lets the message into the room where it will be acted on by the local devices.  It would also be possible that the responses would be signed by the firewall/gateway rather than each individual device providing a signature.  
>     
>  For the second method, any data which is not determinable by the firewall without being a member of the group with the exception of the signing key, is going to be a problem as the signature cannot validated.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body: I think both of these use cases are interesting and definitely worth discussing. The first use case seems quite straightforward to achieve and likely worth making sure it works with Group OSCORE. The firewall still need to be able to fetch information from somewhere, but does not need to be trusted. The second use case is more complicated as the firewall need to be semi-trusted, and there the construction also changes the meaning of the Sender ID as it is now the firewall that has signed rather than the original sender.

comments.author: fpalombini
comments.body:
John I think you reversed first and second use case in your second comment, correct? 

I think the second case (where the gateway only verifies the signatures) is a very valid use case of group OSCORE and should be described (possibly in appendix). The first case, on the contrary, is not necessarily a group OSCORE case. There could be a group OSCORE between the gateway and the firewall/gateway, but that is not fundamental to the scenario: here the middle node is trusted on one side by the external controller, on the other side by the multicast group. He could be considered the endpoint for those communications.

So I suggest we only describe the second case.

issues.body: and application dependent

issues.title: Recude the size of responses with 64 bytes
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
In Group OSCORE with ECDSA and EdDSA signatures, I think the overhead of responses can be cut with a whopping 64 bytes (for 256 bit curves), by removing the signature and calculating the AEAD with an ephemeral-static ECHD key instead of the server's sender key. An ECDSA signature is (r, s) where r = g^x can be seen as an ephemeral Diffie-Hellman public key. 

Current specification:
```
Client					Server
----------------------------------------------
Sender Key				Receiver Key
Reciever Key				Sender Key
Private Sig Key				Public Sig Key
Public Sig Key				Private Sig Key

--------------->
AEAD( client sender key, ... ), (r1 = g^x, s1)
<---------------
AEAD( server sender key, ... ), (r2 = g^y, s2)
```


Optimized solution to reduce message size of repsonses:
```
Client					Server
----------------------------------------------
Sender Key				Receiver Key
Private Sig Key				Public Sig Key
Public DH Key (g^v)			Private SH Key (v)

--------------->
AEAD( client sender key, ... ), (r1 = g^x, s1)
<---------------
AEAD( g^xv, ... )


```
Pros:

- 	Cuts a whopping 64 bytes from responses
- 	g^xv can be calculated while waiting for the repsonse
- 	In deployments with fixed roles the number of asymmetric keys stay the same	

Cons:

- 	In mesh networks the number of asymmetric keys doubles
- 	Signature checking intermediaries is not supported.

This idea seems to work for both ECDSA, deterministic ECDSA and EdDSA. For deterministic algorithms it works as the signed message is never the same due to the inclusion of a sequence number. In the case of EdDSA the client and server has to transform the point in Edwards form to Montgomery form to use the standardized X25519.

(This comment was updated with information on EdDSA and deterministic signatures after suggestions from Erik Thormarker).

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
The amount of reduction depends on the number of nodes in the system:

- 2 nodes   41% reduction in OSCORE overhead (number of bytes)
- 10 nodes  75% reduction in OSCORE overhead (number of bytes)
- 100 nodes 82% reduction in OSCORE overhead (number of bytes)

Such a significant reduction would be very lucrative, especially in mesh networks where the number of key in symmetric solutions grow as n^2. Group OSCORE could e.g. specify two different modes, one that support signature verifying middle-boxes and one modes that does not.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Now covered by the optimized mode.

issues.title: Clarify key id in which messages
issues.author: fpalombini
issues.body:
by @jimsch:

In working through all of the roll over cases I am dealing with, I have a
question.  The key identifier is a required field in all response messages.
Is the group identifier a required field in all response messages or is it
only required under certain circumstances?  The circumstances would be if
the key context is not the same as the (original?) request.  Not too sure
what the answer is going to be if you are looking at a sequence of observe
responses where you would really like to stop sending the group identifier
if it is not needed any more.

issues.title: keeping old context
issues.author: fpalombini
issues.body:
By @jimsch:

In section 8.4 it might be useful to distinguish between two different
instances of the first case.

There is a difference between a server which receives a message using an old
context, which it makes more sense to ignore and a client receiving a
response from a server that is using the same context as the request was
sent in.  It makes more sense to hang onto the context in the second case
than in the first case.  There is also a question of should the server
respond in a different context than the response was in.  That point also
should be clarified.

issues.body:
By @jimsch:

*  Section 1 - In the last paragraph you might want to mention that using
DTLS for doing hop-by-hop protection protects the routing information of the
packet from observers.

issues.title: Editorial
issues.author: fpalombini
issues.body:
By @jimsch:

* Appendix A - I think there may be a problem with the term "member of a
group" between this document and draft-dijk-core-groupcomm.  This document
includes all clients, while that document only incudes the servers.  This
may cause future problems.

issues.title: Echo recovery in multicast cases
issues.author: chrysn
issues.body:
As I understand the current master, replay window recovery should work like this:

* A single server reboots
* Client sends request
* Most servers accept it
* A single server says "4.01 Echo: blah"
* Client sends the same request again to that particular server. It's unicast on the network, uses the same group security context as the original request but has an Echo: blah option and obviously a new sender sequence number.

This triggers the very concerns of ssec-unicast-requests -- someone might send that message to other servers.

(Admittedly that's not a concern for safe requests -- but then again, if it were a safe request, as a server, I'd be tempted to respond successfully right away).

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Is this still a concern with pairwise request? (See latest github.)

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
I think that pairwise would mitigate this, but that means that pairwise becomes mandatory for challenge-response synchronization.

If that is a restriction that is inacceptable (don't know how big a part of group OSCORE pairwise will be), there might be a variation on ssec-synch-challenge-response that can do without: A server, rather than protected 4.01+Echo, might answer unprotected 5.03 (or not at all if multicast), and send an arbitrary request (I'd send GET / Block2:0:0:0 but it really doesn't matter) to the client (or even the whole group of clients if it just comes up and wants to do that eagerly). If that is responded to with an own sequence number (which'll be the case in groupcomm -- on original OSCORE we couldn't enforce that), that is known fresh to the original server, and it can initialize its replay window. This depends on the availability of role reversal and the absence of proxies, so I'd only flesh this out if it solves a real problem.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Just on pairwise: For the algorithms that are expected to be used, the same public key can be used for both signature and pairwise DH. Therefore the only practical limitation of using pairwise seems to be the inability for intermediary nodes to verify responses, since there is no signature. I think verifying signature makes more sense in multicast requests than in unicast responses, so I think this limitation is acceptable. Why not mandate or at least recommend the use of pairwise DH for responses, and mandate it for challenge-response synchronization?

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
> Why not mandate or at least recommend the use of pairwise DH for responses, and mandate it for challenge-response synchronization?

If I understand that right that'd be a quite impactful change on group OSCORE, that's probably better tracked in a separate thread / issue.

For the purpose of receive window recovery, using pairwise is probably good enough to close this issue with some text; from looking in a bit deeper, the cost of calculating the pairwise key appears to be in the same order of magnitude as processing a signed response -- and if pairwise is to become even more widespread, it'll just be less impact to code size for echo recovery.

issues.title: Convenience and security of one key pair for Diffie-Hellman and signing
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Elaborate on the convenience together with the security [DeGabriele] of using the same key pair for Diffie-Hellman (in pairwise mode) and for signing (in group mode). This can extend the text in Section 10.13 "Cryptographic Considerations".


[DeGabriele] Degabriele, J., Lehmann, A., Paterson, K., Smart, N., and M. Strefler, "On the Joint Security of Encryption and Signature in EMV", December 2011. https://eprint.iacr.org/2011/615

issues.title: Align with draft-ietf-cose-countersign security considerations
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
"When either COSE_Encrypt and COSE_Mac is used and more than two parties share the key, data origin authentication is not provided. Any party that knows the message-authentication key can compute a valid authentication tag; therefore, the contents could originate from any one of the parties that share the key.

Countersignatures of COSE_Encrypt and COSE_Mac with short authentication tags do not provide the security properties associated with the same algorithm used in COSE_Sign. To provide 128-bit security against collision attacks, the tag length MUST be at least 256-bits. A countersignature of a COSE_Mac with AES-MAC 256/128 provides at most 64 bits of integrity protection. Similarly, a countersignature of a COSE_Encrypt with AES-CCM-16-64-128 provides at most 32 bits bits of integrity protection."

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Addressed in https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/f3d028120357e9ca4bff427793947dd267e7a453

issues.title: Strange use of countersign
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
The common definition of countersignature in the litterature is:

"add a signature to (a document already signed by **another** person)."

issues.title: Request verification order is undefined.
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
The verification order is currently completely undefined.

Update of repley window must be done after verifing source authentication.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
This seems to already be in the draft 

"Furthermore, the Replay Window MUST be updated only if both the signature verification and the decryption succeed"

issues.title: 80-byte source authentication is a big problem
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
The current design where the sender "countersign" it's own AEAD creates 80-byte source authentication when everything except CCM_8 is used. E.g. AES-CCM, AES-GCM, and ChaCha20-Poly1305.  This make Group OSCORE impossible to use in many situations such as the 75 bytes in some cellular network broadcast (even with CCM_8).
 
It would be very strange to force people wanting to use AES-CCM, AES-GCM, or ChaCha20-Poly1305 or other 16-bit tag algorithms in pair-wise to use 80-byte source authentication, when it can trivially by done with 64 bytes. While the TLS conclusions regarding CCM_8 is misleading, I think there will be a trend toward 128 bit tags. Many deployments for government and financial institutions always use 128 bit tags.

Another big disadvantage with the current design is that the user to chose between more useless in the signature mode and less security in pair-wise. In the signature mode, the tag provides no security and you want as small as possible. For pair-wise many application would definitly want to use 16 bytes tags, e.g. application aligning with the CSNA suite.

8-16 additional bytes overhead for the signature mode makes a big difference. Group OSCORE without the useless AEAD tag could be used, but Group OSCORE with the tag cannot.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
I agree with the reasoning above, but have a question anyway:
Is the AEAD authenticator actually "useless"?  Doesn't it protect against DoSing the signature verifier?

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
This issue was also addressed in version -12, by admitting that the group mode could also use an encryption algorithm without integrity tag as Signature Encryption Algorithm.

If an encryption algorithm with integrity tag is used anyway, the tag does not help against a DoS based on inducing the message recipient to verify a bad signature. As also clarified in version -12 [1][2], the signature verification must happen and be successfully completed before proceeding with the decryption of the COSE object.


[1] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm-12#section-8.2
[2] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm-12#section-8.4

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
>  Is the AEAD authenticator actually "useless"? Doesn't it protect against DoSing the signature verifier?

The verifier could check the AEAD tag on the encrypted part first. The text says that "The server MUST perform signature verification before decrypting the COSE object" (with exceptions only for those that can't), but that's not ruling out verification of the tag. (Granted, many cryptographic APIs don't support doing these things separately).

(Obtaining a valid tag on an encrypted signature is probably as easy or hard as obtaining a valid tag on the encrypted payload -- once an attacker has that, and either can be used to pester the server until the client's request on that seqno gets through and the obtained tag is burned).

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: As per the follow-up side discussion, no further text is needed.

issues.title: Group OSCORE is not secure with the future planned encryption algorithms for the AEAD interface
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
COSE has discussed and are are planning to standardize new encryption algorithms for the AEAD interface after a request from FIDO. The new algorithms would not provide any integrity protection.

The current version of the Group OSCORE draft would not be secure at all with these new algorithms due to the unusual design choice to let the sender countersign it's own AEAD. This could easily be addressed by using a traditional MAC-then-Sign approach.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
See https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/e4b076223354f0904ebbaa370a7d69e1a59ebd55

As discussed, now a recipient endpoint owning the latest group keying material does not store the public keys of sender endpoints that are not current group members. This builds on the Group Manager informing of former group members when rekeying the group.

As a result, proof of group-membership is always achieved, also for messages protected in group mode when using an encryption algorithm that does not provide integrity protection (i.e., there is no tag providing group authentication).

issues.title: Counter Signature Parameters are not signature parameters.
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body: The Counter Signature Parameters are not signature parameters following JOSE, COSE, X.509 terminology. They are part of the public key. The correct thing here is likely to do is to include the public key structure (maybe a CWT, X509, C509) in the external_aad.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Addressed in https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/481188b671ecd49dc4b0c6fc082dd1d09b68556e

issues.title: Group OSCORE should not mandate how things in context are stored
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body: RFC 8613 stays away from such implementation details for very good reasons

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Addressed in https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/b7b044555f43763e0e32d5fcd2312a4032843420

issues.title: Deployments using pairwise only should not be forced to implement signatures.
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body: Pairwise a very important and useful piece of Group OSCORE. As already stated "A special deployment of Group OSCORE is to use pairwise mode only". This make very much sense to have duch deployments. Such deployments should definitly not be forced to implement signatures.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Addressed in https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/7a80990154dc7927a9803a6d9e38143cff21dcf1

issues.title: Key formats, Public key algorithms, and integrity protectioin.
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
The draft does not dicuss key formats at all. Typical formats to use would be CWT, X509 and C509. The draft needs to discuss this at least shortly. 

The public key credential includes the public key algorithm, something that the draft calls signature algorithms.

The public key credential should be included in the external_aad, COSE does not do this automatically for you.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Addressed in https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/b7b044555f43763e0e32d5fcd2312a4032843420   and   https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/481188b671ecd49dc4b0c6fc082dd1d09b68556e

issues.title: Secret Derivation Algorithm
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
The name is a bit strange. According to COSE this is a Key Agreement Algorithm. I suggest changing to "Pairwise Key Agreement Algorithm".

If the signature algorithms is protected in the external_aad, this algorithm should as well.

The key derivation in the Key Agreeent algorithm may not be HKDF. The key derivation included in the key agreement algorithm is used to derive the shared secret, it should not be used to derive the sender keys. The RFC 8613 HKDF Algorithm should be used in the derivation below.

Pairwise Sender Key    = HKDF(Sender Key, Shared Secret, info, L)

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Addressed in https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/b7b044555f43763e0e32d5fcd2312a4032843420   and   https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/481188b671ecd49dc4b0c6fc082dd1d09b68556e

issues.title: When EdDSA are used for both signatues and pairwise, it should be forbidden to use them in other protocols
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body: Using them in other protocols might not be safe

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Addressed in the "Pairwise Keys" section, see commit https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/b7b044555f43763e0e32d5fcd2312a4032843420

issues.title: No Verification of Signatures in Group Mode
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
"For instance, a command to turn a bulb on where the bulb is
   already on does not need the signature to be checked.  In such
   situations, the counter signature needs to be included anyway as part
   of a message protected with the group mode, so that an endpoint that
   needs to validate the signature for any reason has the ability to do
   so."

I don't think this works at all. Assuming a client sends a request to "lock" an open lock, and another group member change it to "unlock". The server answers the client with a "200 OK" stating that it is "locked". Also in the example above, the replay window would not be updated, which likely cause a lot of additional problems.

The kind of "hack" described above seems far worse than just having a group request mode without source authentication. The client always need to know what the server will do cryptographically.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Addressed in the commit https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/1b559a0d4fbc99b1e30f1c3c31209419f986ace9

issues.title: Privacy and tracking
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
The current -11 design allows an attacker to link messages from different groups as long as the public key is the same (which it likely will be). I think group oscore should probably fulfill something like 

- Group privacy (an attacker that is not a member of both groups should not be able to link messages between groups)

I think that can be done by signing a HMAC that is not sent on the wire (at least that stops the trivial attack), or by encrypting the signature. (a signature verifying proxy would have to be a limited group member that can verify but not decrypt)

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: As discussed, now addressed by encrypting the counter signature, see https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/0b74642065c166019c311b7114dde4824ac6b5a1

issues.title: Clarify derivation of Group Encryption Key
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
In Section 2.1.6 "Group Encryption Key", explicitly mention that the 'id' element of the 'info' array is the empty byte string.

This is consistent with the derivation of the Common IV inherited from https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8613#section-3.2.1

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: And fix an error: the value of L should not be the size of the output of the HKDF. It should be the size of the keys used the Signature Encryption Algorithm, consistently with the derivation of the Sender/Recipient key.

issues.title: Merge section 6.2 and 6.4
issues.author: gselander
issues.body:
From Section 13.12 :
"As discussed in [Section 6.2](https://core-wg.github.io/oscore-groupcomm/draft-ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm.html#sec-synch-seq-num), a Replay Window may be initialized as not valid "

Section 6.2 is essentially one paragraph long and, does not discuss the above. It can be merged with 6.4 which is also about replay protection. The reference in 13.12 also needs to be fixed.

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body: Is there any difference between the SSN being out of sync and the replay window being initialized as not valid?

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Good question, which text are you reading? Perhaps we wouldn't use the term "initialized as not valid" for SSN being out of sync, but they can both serve as examples of how a replay window became invalid.

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
The place I've seen "not synchronized or the RW is invalid" is in the
commit that fixed this issue (hence replying here).

I think the expression "not having / knowing a valid Replay Window" is
the most descriptive, as SSN "synchronization" to me reads like there is
a tighter coupling than there actually is.

So maybe

-A server may not be synchronized[...]
+A server may not have a valid Replay Window (typically stemming from
loss of mutable security context in any form of
{{ssec-loss-mutable-context}}).

pulls.title: Move signature to Payload and Compression updates
pulls.author: emanjon
pulls.body:
- Move signature to Payload: Having the signature in the option is bad for two reasons: I makes fragmentation far worse, and it means that the recipient need to look up the signature length, just to parse the OSCORE option. For these reasons the signature belongs in the payload.

- The Group OSCORE spec seem to have been written from an old version of the OSCORE draft and never updated. I updated the compression section with subsections and added the note of IANA. Someone should probably go through the draft and align it with draft-ietf-core-object-security-15

comments.author: fpalombini
comments.body: Thanks John, your text was included in 81b31aa9393 . More updates are coming.

pulls.title: Optimized mode and some editorial changes to intro and compression se…
pulls.author: emanjon
pulls.body:
…ction

-	The abstract felt old. I replaced it with text from the introduction.
-	I-D.dijk-core-groupcomm-bis is already a normative reference, which obsoletes RFC7390. Referencing to RFC7390 does formally not make much sense (unless you want to discuss something historically).
-	Most of header compression was just respecification of RFC 8613.
-	Implements the suggestion of an optimized mode as suggested in Issue #13

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Integrated in v-07.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
@marco-tiloca-sics Good point about being more explicit. I actually think is valuable to reference an existing encoding of public keys providing also key type and curve, like CRED_X in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-lake-edhoc-05#section-3.3.3.

Also, there is a discussion about format for public keys in COSE, which if it is specified probably will be referenced by EDHOC instead of CRED_X. I would be good if there is a common format used in all these instances. For the time being I propose that we reference CRED_X with empty text string subject name, and keep track of the COSE activity.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
We should consider replace the NIST reference with SECG [1] to harmonize with EDHOC [2].

[1] https://www.secg.org/sec1-v2.pdf
[2] https://github.com/lake-wg/edhoc/issues/107

(edit) ... but the commits in [3] mainly refers to the NIST spec. so I propose we keep it as is for the time being.

[2] https://github.com/lake-wg/edhoc/issues/108

reviews.author: marco-tiloca-sics
reviews.body:
It looks good to me; we can give more details on one point.

For the two HKDF invocations in Section 2.3.1, we can define more explicitly how the public keys are expressed when concatenated to form IKM-Sender and IKM-Recipient.

Given a public key, that can simply be:

* For OKP signature keys, the compressed 'x' coordinate, i.e. what would be expressed in the key parameter -2 of a corresponding COSE Key.

* For EC2 signature keys, the 'x' coordinate followed by the 'y' coordinate in this order, i.e. what would be expressed in the key parameters -2 and -3 of a corresponding COSE Key.

This should be sufficient, i.e. it shouldn't be needed to have a more structured encoding of public keys providing also key type and curve, e.g. like done for CRED_X in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-lake-edhoc-05#section-3.3.3

pulls.title: 1. Introduction (and Abstract)
pulls.author: emanjon
pulls.body:
- Abstract and the beginning of the intro seems to have been written before pairwise. Pairwise a very important and useful piece of Group OSCORE.

- "pairwise mode, two group members exchange Group OSCORE requests"
This does not align witf the terminology that group request are sent to all members.

- "A special deployment of Group OSCORE is to use pairwise mode only"
  "This mode is defined in Section 8 and MUST be supported."
Pairwise only is is a very valid use case. Deployments using pairwise only should not be forced to implement signatures.

- "supports all COSE algorithms"
Only signature algorithms.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Manually addressed in branch "v-12", see commit https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/7a80990154dc7927a9803a6d9e38143cff21dcf1

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
-The signature parameters are not signature parametes, they are part of the public key algorithm. The format of the public key algorithm depends on the types of credentials used, with CWT it is a COSE key type and Key Parameters, in X.509 it is a SubjectPublicKeyInfoAlgorithm. The public key algorith would typically be stored with the keys.

-The use of AEAD with signatures and without signatures are two completely different use cases with completely different security properties. It does not make sense to have a signle AEAD algorithm here as it increases source authentication with up to 16 bytes.

-Pairwise only deployments should not be forced to implement signatures.

-"Secret Derivation Algorithm MUST take value from the "Value" column of the "COSE Algorithms" Registry {{COSE.Algorithms}}" It makes no sense to mandate how the context in implemented in detail.

-When EdDSA are used for both signatues and pairwise, it should be forbidden to use them in other protocols.

- I don't understand this parameter obsession. It is extremely long and makes the whole specification and protocol feel extremly complicated. Frankly, I don't see much use at all.

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
The name Secret Derivation Algorithm  is a bit strange. According to COSE this is a Key Agreement Algorithm. I suggest changing to "Pairwise Key Agreement Algorithm".
If the signature algorithms is protected in the external_aad, this algorithm should as well.
The key derivation in the Key Agreeent algorithm may not be HKDF. The key derivation included in the key agreement algorithm is used to derive the shared secret, it should not be used to derive the sender keys. The RFC 8613 HKDF Algorithm should be used in the derivation below.
Pairwise Sender Key = HKDF(Sender Key, Shared Secret, info, L)

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
The draft does not dicuss key formats at all. Typical formats to use would be CWT, X509 and C509. The draft needs to discuss this at least shortly.
The public key credential includes the public key algorithm, something that the draft calls signature algorithms.
The public key credential should be included in the external_aad, COSE does not do this automatically for you.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Manually addressed in branch "v-12", see commit https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/b7b044555f43763e0e32d5fcd2312a4032843420

comments.author: emanjon
comments.body:
- Even if CounterSignature is used, the algorithm is a signature algorithm, and not a counter signature algorithm. 

- Not sure if all algorithms need to be protected, but if the signature algorithm is protected, the pairwise kdf alg should also be protected.

- The sender's public key needs to be integrity protected, COSE does not do that for you.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Manually addressed in branch "v-12", see commit https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/481188b671ecd49dc4b0c6fc082dd1d09b68556e

pulls.title: Appendix F, G, H
pulls.author: emanjon
pulls.body: I suggest to just remove these 3 appendixes. Appendix F seems completely insecure. Appendix G and H discusses things related to the key which might be in CWT, X.509, or C509 format. Providing integrity protection of the key parameters is easily done by adding the public key credential to the external_aad which should probably be done for other reasons.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body: Manually addressed in branch "v-12", see commit https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/commit/1b559a0d4fbc99b1e30f1c3c31209419f986ace9

but why?

RFC 8949 does not mention "nil".
RFC 8610 has "nil" as a way to specify a CBOR null ("null" works too), but there is no CBOR simple value "nil".  The second paragraph of RFC 8610 may be  a bit misleading...
That was in an old commit and the change was reverted :-) That changelog item is not present now in v -14, which only uses CBOR simple value "null".

pulls.title: Response handling and security properties
pulls.author: marco-tiloca-sics
pulls.body:
This PR is about the following points:

* Explicit handling of multiple non-notification responses from the same server to the same group request. The handling relies on the same rationale used for notifications, in order to detect replays and ensure ordering of responses from the same server. From a general point of view, this relates to the issue at https://github.com/core-wg/core-responses/issues/2

* Improved presentation of the security properties ensured by Group OSCORE, by following more closely the parlance and structure used for OSCORE in RFC 8613.

* Improved listing of operations defined for the group mode that are inherited by the pairwise mode.

* Have "SHOULD" (not "MUST") for using the group mode to protect a request intended to multiple recipients. An exception is a Deterministic Request as defined in [1], which is always protected with the pairwise mode, even in the case where it is intended to multiple servers.

* Editorial fixes.


[1] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-amsuess-core-cachable-oscore/

comments.body: Nit: uniquess -> uniqueness
To terminate a _Non-Notification Group Exchange_ it would be about deleting the associated Token? Is it worth mentioning how the termination is done here or elsewhere?

_the associated Response Number is initialized to the Partial IV of the first successfully verified non-notification response_ Meaning the first one that actually contains a Partial IV? (As the first one may not).

Could be rephrased to avoid double negative?

_That is, if the server receives an observation request and does not register the observation, then any following 2.xx response from the server to that request MUST NOT be a notification._

-> 

_That is, if the server receives an observation request and registers the observation, then any following 2.xx response from the server to that request MUST be a notification._

Is it needed to list these points here? The beginning paragraph of this section says _"The following differences also apply."_, so it is focusing on the differences. The points listed here seem to be the same as in {ssec-verify-request}

reviews.author: rikard-sics
reviews.body: I have checked the PR and left a few comments. To me the content looks good and consistent with our earlier discussions.

comments.body: Can be closed after discussions with Marco. (The diff is actually compared to Section 8.2 of RFC8613).
As a comparison, RFC 7641 uses quite high-level language on what terminating an observation means. We can add that the CoAP Token associated with the corresponding request is freed up.

Yes, however:

- This has to be read together with the later sentence: " Given a group request, implementations need to make sure that the corresponding non-notification response from a server without Partial IV is considered the oldest from that server."

- This text has the same construction and uses the same parlance as the text in Section 4.1.3.5.2 of RFC 8613 about how OSCORE handles notifications.

It's good to mirror as much as possible what OSCORE says for notifications.
Sounds better, thanks!

comments.author: rikard-sics
comments.body:
It looks good to me also. The only point I had was to maybe have a more descriptive title for the web link figure.
`{: #fig-web-link-example title="The Web Link." artwork-align="center"}`

Something like the below perhaps?
_Usage of the "gosc" attribute in a web link_

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
Thanks @rikard-sics , good point! Just to emphasize that it is an example, we may go for:

> Example of using the "gosc" attribute in a web link.

pulls.title: Replace CCS abbreviation with its full form
pulls.author: chrysn
pulls.body:
So far, it was used 1x in abbreviated form, and 2x as "CWT Claims Sets (CCS)". The abbreviation was problematic the way it was used while being a reference into RFC8392, it was not defined there.

---

I'm not 100% happy with dropping the term "CCS" because it having an abbreviation is a good pointer for users to see that this is an established, good and compact thing to use (right?), but I'd rather spare readers the confusion of clicking through to 8392 and not finding the letters "CCS".

I'd be happy with any better handling of the possible confusion, this is just the best I'm coming up with.

pulls.title: KID discovery: may be pairwise
pulls.author: chrysn
pulls.body:
Quoting a review that's being written:

> * 9 / 9.1, " a sender can use the pairwise mode to protect a message
  sent to (but not intended for) multiple recipients": This refers to
  the service roughly outlined in 9.1, but 9.1 describes "a resource to
  which a client can send a group request".

This proposes a fix, and makes up for the added text by removing a sentence.

pulls.title: gid-ex: Enhance consideration input for epoch length in Gid-reusing GMs
pulls.author: chrysn
pulls.body:
This is a proposal from my upcoming review:

> C, "Thus, the expected highest rate for addition/removal of group
  members and consequent group rekeying should be taken into account for
  a proper dimensioning of the Group Epoch size." When the GM is capable
  of reassigning GIDs, is this really a concern? I'd expect that if
  triggers to rekeyings happen with a frequency in the order of
  magnitude of the rekeying time, then the rekeyings themselves would be
  delayed rather than churning through parallel rekeyings. (See also the
  comment about "undue delay" -- and if that wording is not accepted,
  the GM can still make the "evict device" operation take some time). So
  rekeyings would always be roughly ordered, and even a nibble of group
  epoch values would by far suffice.

pulls.title: Change replay-protection-non-notifications section
pulls.author: chrysn
pulls.body:
In my review at https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/yAiNmM9_FxhSIvmXpt4WGt8bBx0, I wrote:

>   In particular, I'm playing around with wording updates for 6.4.1 -- if
>   this item is acted on before I've made a more concrete suggestion via
>   PR, please remind me to revisit that section.

These are the changes that came out of said playing-around. They are certainly not suitable for direct inclusion, but I think they could be the base for a clearer paragraph. In particular, this

* shift the focus from the differences between single responses, Observe and non-notification exchanges to the commonality, showing how the general rules apply in principle (but can be simplified for special cases),
* remove the limitation that Observe and non-notification exchanges can not be mixed (Why not? That'd be up to the document that describes the new options that introduce non-notification exchanges.), and
* makes things more opt-in (replay protection is only needed for non-idempotent response handlers, ordering is wholly optional)

See also a few comments inline.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
This was addressed when addressing the topic of unified handling of multiple responses at large in https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/pull/107 , now merged and added to version -19 of the Internet Draft [1].

[1] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-core-oscore-groupcomm-19

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: There is still room to remove redundant information, also in the parts I have edited. So this is still work in progress TBC.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: This became a monster PR. The main ambition was trying to clarify some parts where I think the motivation was spread out over multiple sections, which lead me to some rewrites. At the same time I fixed some of the issues and changes proposed in the shepherd's review.

pulls.title: Freshness and ordering
pulls.author: gselander
pulls.body: Working on this cluster of issues.

comments.body: `A server may not be synchronized with a client's Sender Sequence Number, or a Replay Window may be initialized as invalid (see {{ssec-loss-mutable-context}}). The server can either retrieve a new Group OSCORE Security Context, or synchronize with the clients' Sender Sequence Numbers before resuming to accept incoming messages from other group members.`

`Assuming that the other endpoint is honest, Group OSCORE provides relative ordering of received messages. For a given Group OSCORE Security Context, the received Partial IV (when included) allows the recipient endpoint to determine the order in which requests or responses were sent by the other endpoint. In case the Partial IV was omitted in a response, this indicates that it was the oldest response from the sender endpoint to the corresponding request (like notification responses in OSCORE, see {{Section 7.4.1 of RFC8613}}). A received response is not older than the corresponding request.`

`As in OSCORE, Group OSCORE provides only the guarantee that the request is not older than the Group OSCORE Security Context used to protect it. Other aspects of freshness are discussed in {{sec-freshness}}.`
`Like in OSCORE (see {{Section 12.5 of RFC8613}}), a server may verify the aliveness of the client by using the CoAP Echo Option {{RFC9175}} as described in {{sec-synch-challenge-response}}.`
Do we need the paragraph "More formally, ..."?
Why "would" the elder member eventually re-join? Is it necessarily so, or should it be "could"?

OLD
The client MUST stop processing responses from a server, if those have
NEW
The client MUST stop processing responses from a server, if a response has
Not necessarily, it can be removed.
"could" is fine

Even better:

NEW:
The client MUST stop processing a response from a server, if that response has
Why leave a choice to do it upon leaving, or before re-joining? It may be simpler to limit it to one case: "upon leaving the group"

Considering the discovery method described in the end of "Message Processing in Pairwise Mode", and in "Pre-Conditions", can it make more sense to say one of the following?
_there is at most a single valid response and only from one_
or
_there is at most a single protected response and only from one_
Seems to be repeating very similar text from line 1254

Correct, the previous paragraph (quoted below) should have been deleted, keeping only the paragraph in the comment.

`In addition, the following applies if the server intends to reply with multiple responses, within the long exchange established by the corresponding request.`

Yes, it's definitely only about a valid response. The first option looks good to use.

`there is at most a single valid response and only from one ...`

It is not a choice.

"re-join" has been used in previous sections to denote a current group member that does not leave the group but sends a new Join Request to the Group Manager for obtaining a new Sender ID etc. In that case, there is no leaving to refer to.

If, instead, there is a leaving (irrespective of joining the group again or not after that), that's when the endpoint does what is described in the quoted text.

The last sentence is perhaps correct, but gives the impression that response number can be updated if the response is not received within a long exchange. How about 
NEW
- If the verification of the countersignature fails, the client: i) SHALL stop processing the response; and ii) SHALL NOT update the Response Number associated with the server.
I got the impression when reading through that there are other instances of redundant "in case of long exchange", I'll try to find them.
Addressed in https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/pull/107/commits/f36e4cee74663796bae6e986400f8ae205e8ba1f

pulls.title: Christian's Review of v -21
pulls.author: marco-tiloca-sics
pulls.body: This PR addresses Christian's review of version -21, archived at: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/tPPSsrFMPZId_7Q7OrmbgN1DCdw/

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body: Thanks, LGTM where I may say so.

reviews.author: rikard-sics
reviews.body: Except for my comment below things look good to me, as aligned with our internal discussions and the discussion we had with Christian.

comments.body: It's better to have the reference to section 13.9 here use markdown references instead. It should be referring to section _{#ssec-unicast-requests}_.
Thanks, now fixed in https://github.com/core-wg/oscore-groupcomm/pull/108/commits/d95ec712b8425e6e39601017db82ccfb1c0146ef

pulls.title: Editorial changes to intro
pulls.author: emanjon
pulls.body:
Should explain that DTLS is not an e2e solution
Should explain already in intro that the pairwise keys are not group keys.
(vice verse) makes no sense for bi-directional DTLS.

pulls.title: Christian's implementation comments
pulls.author: marco-tiloca-sics
pulls.body:
This PR addresses the comments from Christian Amsüss archived at https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/oQT5vcbEsui9fvf7P9QH4PEsX-c/

In addition to that:

* Where appropriate, it replaces "AEAD nonce" with "nonce" and "AEAD key" with "key", consistent with the fact that the Group Encryption Algorithm might not be an AEAD algorithm.

* For endpoints that use non-authenticated encryption, it makes A128CBC mandatory to implement as non-authenticated Group Encryption Algorithm.

* It clarifies that the HKDF Algorithm must be an HMAC-based HKDF.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Looks good to me.

I would remove "in fact" and just put this as:
_The constructed nonce is used as AEAD nonce by the AEAD Algorithm (see {{ssec-common-context-aead-alg}}) and by the Group Encryption Algorithm when this is an AEAD algorithm (see {{ssec-common-context-cs-enc-alg}})._

comments.body:
```suggestion
* Implementation's name: aiocoap

* Available at: https://codeberg.org/aiocoap/aiocoap

* Description: A Python CoAP library with support for multiple transports and security mechanisms. The library provides also utility programs.

* Implementation's level of maturity: Stable support for OSCORE; Group OSCORE is WIP.

* The implementation supports:

  * The group mode and the pairwise mode.
  * Mapping of public keys for the curve Ed25519 into Montgomery coordinates to use with X25519.
  * The following COSE encryption algorithms: 1-3, 10-13, 24, 30-33
  * The following HKDF algorithms: HKDF SHA-256, -384, -512.
  * The following COSE signature algorithms: EdDSA on Ed25519, ECDSA w/ SHA-256 on P-256
  * The following COSE key agreement algorithms: ECDH on P-256 and curve25519.
  * The following authentication credential format: currently n/a (user provides pairs of credentials and keys)

* Version compatibility: -23

* Licensing: MIT

* Implementation experience: Mostly smooth; the differentiation between the regular and the group AEAD algorithm was tedious and error prone (because Group OSCORE largely relies on OSCORE extension points that were anticipated, but that was not).

* Contact information: Christian Amsüss - christian@amsuess.com

* Information last updated on: 2024-12-17
```

```suggestion
  * (ChaCha20/Poly1305, ChaCha20/Poly1305), for the case B2 above.
  
  Interoperability was not yet achieved in scenarios in which different AEAD algorithms were used for pairwise and group encryption algorithm.
```
